entities.name: Spaying or Neutering
entities.description: Surgical removal of reproductive organs in pets. In females, this means the ovaries and usually the uterus are removed, and in males, it means the testicles are removed. This procedure decreases the likelihood of certain types of cancers and eliminates the possibility of your pet becoming pregnant or fathering unwanted puppies.

entities.name: Bone and Joint Problems
entities.description: Bulldogs are prone to a number of different musculoskeletal problems, including dysplasia in hips and elbows, osteochondritis dissecans (OCD), and torn cranial cruciate ligament.

entities.name: Spinal Deformities
entities.description: Bulldogs are more likely than other canines to be born with spinal deformities (a condition called hemivertebrae), which may lead to spinal cord damage, instability, or disability.

entities.name: Eye Problems
entities.description: Bulldogs can inherit or develop a number of different eye conditions, including Distichiasis, Entropion, Dry eye (KCS), and Cherry eye.

entities.name: Bladder or Kidney Stones
entities.description: Bulldogs are more likely to develop kidney or bladder stones than other breeds. These stones are painful and can cause blood in urine, inability to urinate, or straining to urinate.

entities.name: Respiratory Distress Syndrome
entities.description: Also known as brachycephalic syndrome, this disease affects dogs with a short nose, like Bulldogs. It leads to a narrow and obstructed airway, causing breathing difficulties, exercise intolerance, loud breathing, coughing, bluish gums, or fainting.

entities.name: Bleeding Disorders
entities.description: Bulldogs are prone to bleeding disorders, which can cause serious health issues.

entities.name: Von Willebrand’s disease
entities.description: A blood clotting disorder frequently found in Bulldogs. It can cause severe bleeding during serious injury or surgery.

entities.name: Reproductive Difficulties
entities.description: Breeds with a large head and small pelvis like Bulldogs are more prone to difficulties during the birthing process. A C-section is often required for the health of the mother and puppies.

entities.name: Heart Disease
entities.description: Bulldogs are prone to multiple types of heart disease, which can occur both early and later in life. Early detection often allows treatment with medication that usually prolongs the pet’s life for many years.

entities.name: Skin Problems
entities.description: Bulldogs are susceptible to different kinds of skin infections and diseases, including yeast infections and seborrhea, which can cause itching, redness, and hair loss.

entities.name: Mange
entities.description: A condition caused by an overabundance of microscopic mites that live in the hair follicles of dogs. It can cause dry, irritated, hairless lesions and secondary skin infections.

entities.name: Laryngeal Paralysis
entities.description: A disease that can develop in older Bulldogs, where the vocal cords become paralyzed and hang down into the airway. It can cause noisy breathing, exercise intolerance, and in severe cases, difficulty breathing.

entities.name: Cancer
entities.description: A leading cause of death in older dogs. Bulldogs are more prone to get cancer in their golden years. Many cancers are curable by surgical removal, and some types are treatable with chemotherapy.

entities.name: Dental Abnormalities
entities.description: Teeth abnormalities are often genetically induced and are relatively common in Bulldogs. These can include malocclusion, oligodontia, and misaligned teeth.

entities.name: English Bulldog
entities.description: The English Bulldog is an affectionate, easygoing, and lovable breed. They are quiet, good with kids and other pets, and make excellent guard dogs. They are adaptable to a wide variety of living conditions and have an outgoing and friendly personality. However, they can be gassy, drool a lot, make a lot of snorting, snuffling, and wheezing noises, and may snore. They can become overweight easily if not exercised regularly and can be rambunctious and rowdy, especially as a puppy. They are sensitive, mature slowly, and can be possessive of toys and food, tending to show dominance.

entities.name: Dental Disease
entities.description: Dental disease is the most common chronic problem in pets, affecting 80% of all dogs by age two. It starts with tartar build-up on the teeth and progresses to infection of the gums and roots of the teeth. If not prevented or treated, it can lead to loss of teeth and damage to the kidneys, liver, heart, and joints.

entities.name: Infections
entities.description: Bulldogs are susceptible to bacterial and viral infections such as parvo, rabies, and distemper. Many of these infections are preventable through vaccination.

entities.name: Obesity
entities.description: Obesity can be a significant health problem in Bulldogs. It is a serious disease that may cause or worsen joint problems, metabolic and digestive disorders, back pain and heart disease.

entities.name: Parasites
entities.description: All kinds of worms and bugs can invade your English Bulldog’s body, inside and out. Everything from fleas and ticks to ear mites can infest her skin and ears. Hookworms, roundworms, heartworms, and whipworms can get into her system in a number of ways: drinking unclean water, walking on contaminated soil, or being bitten by an infected mosquito.

entities.name: Dental Disease
entities.description: The most common chronic problem in pets, affecting 80% of all dogs by age two. Bulldogs are more likely than other dogs to have problems with their teeth. It starts with tartar build-up on the teeth and progresses to infection of the gums and roots of the teeth. If not prevented or treated, it can lead to loss of teeth and damage to kidneys, liver, heart, and joints, potentially shortening the Bulldog's life span by one to three years.

entities.name: Infections
entities.description: Bulldogs are susceptible to bacterial and viral infections such as parvo, rabies, and distemper. Many of these infections are preventable through vaccination.

entities.name: Obesity
entities.description: A significant health problem in Bulldogs. It may cause or worsen joint problems, metabolic and digestive disorders, back pain and heart disease. Overfeeding and lack of exercise can lead to obesity.

entities.name: Parasites
entities.description: Various types of worms and bugs can invade a Bulldog's body, inside and out. These parasites can cause pain, discomfort, and even death. Some of these parasites can be transmitted to humans and are a serious concern for everyone.

entities.name: Bone and Joint Problems
entities.description: A number of different musculoskeletal problems have been reported in Bulldogs. These include dysplasia in hips and elbows, osteochondritis dissecans (OCD), and torn cranial cruciate ligament.

entities.name: Spinal Deformities
entities.description: Bulldogs are more likely than other canines to be born with spinal deformities (a condition called hemivertebrae), which may lead to spinal cord damage, instability, or disability.

entities.name: Eye Problems
entities.description: Bulldogs can inherit or develop a number of different eye conditions, some of which may cause blindness if not treated right away, and most of which can be extremely painful. These include Distichiasis, Entropion, Dry eye (KCS), and Cherry eye.

entities.name: Bladder or Kidney Stones
entities.description: Bulldogs are more likely to develop kidney or bladder stones than other breeds. These stones are painful and can cause blood in urine, inability to urinate, or straining to urinate.

entities.name: Respiratory Distress Syndrome
entities.description: This disease, also known as brachycephalic syndrome, affects dogs with a short nose, like Bulldogs. It leads to a narrow and obstructed airway, causing breathing difficulties, exercise intolerance, loud breathing, coughing, bluish gums, or fainting.

entities.name: Bleeding Disorders
entities.description: Bulldogs are prone to bleeding disorders, which can cause serious health issues.

entities.name: Von Willebrand’s disease
entities.description: A blood clotting disorder frequently found in Bulldogs. It can result in severe bleeding during serious injury or surgery.

entities.name: Reproductive Difficulties
entities.description: Breeds with a large head and small pelvis, like Bulldogs, are more prone to difficulties during the birthing process. A C-section is often required for the health of the mother and puppies.

entities.name: Heart Disease
entities.description: Bulldogs are prone to multiple types of heart disease, which can occur both early and later in life. Early detection often allows for treatment with medication that usually prolongs the pet’s life for many years.

entities.name: Skin Problems
entities.description: Bulldogs are susceptible to different kinds of skin infections and diseases, including yeast infections and seborrhea. These diseases can cause itching, discomfort, hair loss, and a characteristic odor.

entities.name: Mange
entities.description: Bulldogs can develop an overabundance of Demodex mites, leading to dry, irritated, hairless lesions. Secondary skin infections may occur.

entities.name: Laryngeal Paralysis
entities.description: Older Bulldogs may develop this disease, in which the vocal cords become paralyzed and hang down into the airway. This can cause noisy breathing, exercise intolerance, and in severe cases, difficulty breathing.

entities.name: Cancer
entities.description: Cancer is a leading cause of death in older dogs. Bulldogs are more prone to get cancer in their golden years. Many cancers are curable by surgical removal, and some types are treatable with chemotherapy.

entities.name: Dental Abnormalities
entities.description: Teeth abnormalities are often genetically induced and are relatively common in Bulldogs. These can include malocclusion (bad bite), oligodontia (few teeth present), and misaligned teeth.

entities.name: Dental Disease
entities.description: Dental disease is the most common chronic problem in pets, affecting 80% of all dogs by age two. Bulldogs are more likely than other dogs to have problems with their teeth. It starts with tartar build-up on the teeth and progresses to infection of the gums and roots of the teeth. If not prevented or treated, it can lead to loss of teeth and damage to kidneys, liver, heart, and joints, potentially shortening the Bulldog's lifespan by one to three years.

entities.name: Infections
entities.description: Bulldogs are susceptible to bacterial and viral infections such as parvo, rabies, and distemper. Many of these infections are preventable through vaccination.

entities.name: Obesity
entities.description: Obesity can be a significant health problem in Bulldogs. It is a serious disease that may cause or worsen joint problems, metabolic and digestive disorders, back pain and heart disease.

entities.name: Parasites
entities.description: Various types of worms and bugs can invade a Bulldog's body, inside and out. These parasites can cause pain, discomfort, and even death, so it’s important to test for them on a regular basis and use preventive medication as necessary.
